Reviews.Title: “Mixed bag”
Reviews.Author: uptowngirl57
Reviews.Content: I knew what to expect from the other reviews on Trip Advisor, yet I was hoping for the best.The best I can say is that it was an "experience" and I kind of know what a monk feels like now. --Pluses: the interesting church and a plethora of great little neighborhood places to grab something to eat, either casual (stand up at the bar) or full blown Mama's-in-the-kitchen meals. --It's cheap --You are out and about and really only shower and sleep, so if you don't mind the austerity, it's a good value. --The staff is nice and helpful --It's clean, just worn --Minuses: The biggest minus was definitely the Spartan room - tiny, bare bones, ill-kept, but others include: --Our window was oval (you can see it if you look at the front of the building to the left of the Church) and opened onto the piazza, which in turn fronted a busy street. There is a hospital less than a mile away so the ambulances were going all night - if you stay, get away from the street side. --Our group had 4 rooms total and none of them looked like the rooms on the website with high ceilings, etc. - all were small and just barely okay. --The breakfast is as bare bones as the rest of the place. We only ate there the first day and afterward, went across the street where hot, fresh pastries were mouthwatering. For 5 euro we got two coffees and 2 croissants. --The location would have been okay if it were just my husband and I, who exercise a lot; but our group of 8 included my 80-year-old parents, who are in great shape and kept up with us through Rome, Venice, and Sorrento but for whom I would not have recommended walking to anywhere from the hotel. So it was taxis, which can get expensive. If you don't mind walking it would have been okay.

Reviews.Title: “A unique place to stay in a perfect location”
Reviews.Author: Shawney M
Reviews.Content: This was my first trip to Rome, and I must first comment on how great the location was - 15min walk from the Colosseum, nearest station 5 minutes walk away (easy to get on this line from the airport). Me and my boyfriend stayed at this hotel, and our only surprise upon arrival was that the double bed booked was actually two singled pushed together. Still, with shared duvet etc. comfort was not disturbed too much. Our room was a good size, and faced onto the street. It was never really too noisy, but coming from London I don't know how much I can comment on this! The concept of the hotel in this old monastery was great. It was lovely to have to walk past the church to get our breakfast in the morning. Lovely architecture. Breakfast was always filling, eat as much as you want... was always plenty to chose from. Would really recommend taking the lift to the roof garden - we did not realize this was here until the last night, but it was absolutely lovely, great views of Rome. A lot of people have commented how difficult this hotel was to find - if you had looked at pictures shown online I'd say it was actually pretty easy. Hotels of this style just don't have grand entrances!

Reviews.Title: “Mind-blowing concept, Terrible Execution.”
Reviews.Author: Digiwolf
Reviews.Content: It is one of these rare moments, that you really want to write something positive but you can't. A hotel next to a wonderful church; an amazing concept, yet so terribly executed. The natural character of the hotel is mind-blowing... However, it falls apart: strong smell of sewage everywhere, especially next to the breakfast area. We couldn't have our breakfast properly, my mother wanted to vomit. Walls and ceilings haven't been painted for at least a decade (or at least this is the impression). Our rooms were large with comfortable beds. When I opened the door of the toilet, it wasn't cleaned quite evidently: balls of human hair on the floor, used plaster with blood, dirty shower area, mould and filth everywhere! A disappointment... Our second room had a strong smell of smoke! Is it possible to allow guests to smoke in the hotel rooms? I couldn't believe it! What happened to the smoke detector on the ceiling? I don't want to think about what would happen in the case of emergency (fire etc.)... TO MANAGEMENT: Renovate the place, it's really a pity... I didn't mind the falling tiles from the wall, but at least make it squeaky clean! Cleanness is the basic!

Reviews.Title: “A little out of the way, but otherwise perfect!”
Reviews.Author: lizglowark
Reviews.Content: This hotel is a little bit outside of the tourist area, but near two bus lines. It is also near to a metro, just about a 5 minutes walks. It is in a working chapel and is located next to a museum. We stayed in the area that used to be the monastery. The breakfast was different than what we were used to, and the internet was chargeable, though pretty cheap. The room was simple, but comfortable enough. Value for money, it was definitely worth it.

Reviews.Title: “Neat place”
Reviews.Author: sc00mes
Reviews.Content: The Domus Sessoriana is a really neat place and the rooms are spacious and clean. The location was lacking as it felt like we were far from most sites and there wasn't much going on nearby. If you like a quiet place this is for you!

Reviews.Title: “A Hotel with character!”
Reviews.Author: Mary W
Reviews.Content: This hotel was so different as it was actually a monastery at one time. It is very old, but has so much beauty and character. The hallways are massive with a beautiful view. Our room was a good size for 3 people and the bathroom was very large. It is a little out of the way, a couple miles from the train. There are a few great restaurants nearby and my daughters and myself felt safe walking at night. They also had a pretty nice continental breakfast each morning. Very pleasant and helpful staff.

Reviews.Title: “AWFUL!”
Reviews.Author: twocorgisguilfordct
Reviews.Content: Very misleading photos. I had a reservation in Jan. 2012 for 3 nights. Cold and creepy, dimly lit entrance. I was taken to a room on the left side of the hotel. There were 4 or 5 large garbage bags piled in the hallway with dirty towels. The furniture in the room was old and damaged. The shower had mold. No security latch on the door. A 12" tv from the 70's with a dirty remote. The smell of urine in the bathrooom. I went down to talk to the man at the desk , he offered no concern. He told me I must be tired or hungry and to read the reviews everyone is always happy. He pretty much dismissed me with his rude arrogant attitude. There would be absolutely no refund... I gave him the room key back & left, he said nothing. Terribly disappointed.

Reviews.Title: “What a cool hotel!”
Reviews.Author: CalemGunn
Reviews.Content: The history of this location is unbelievable! The property is almost 2000 years old, has been owned by the emporer's mother, served as a monastery, and houses relics from the crucifiction of Christ! Check out their website, and stay here if you're looking for a very reasonably priced room in a safe neighborhood, just a little off the beaten path, with a ton of history. The rooms were HUGE (15 foot ceilings) and very clean. The bed was resonably comfortable and the staff kept the place clean. We had a room that overlooked the monastic garden, and would open our double windows to see priests strolling through it in the morning and evening. The included breakfast was adequate but not fancy. Yogurt, juice, breads, spreads, american coffee and tea, fruit - just enough to get your day started until your first lunch break. Don't let the hotel's location on the city map discourage you - it is within walking distance to just about everything, including a nearby metro. We walked home from the Vatican with no trouble, since there is SO much to see and do on the way. The colisseum is just down the road. Don't forget to check out the Basilica attached to the hotel - the architecture is beautiful, and the relics are said to be from the actual crucifiction of Christ. Be respectful of those on pilgrimages, as this is a holy spot. The friendly, english-speaking staff can arrange a number of day trips and guided tours for you at a resonable price - we went to Pompeii for the day - definitely worth it. They will also hold your bulky key for you so you don't lose it during the day. I would recommend that you stay here at least once. You won't get the frills of some other, more expensive hotels, but it will certainly add to the quality of your Roman experience. You will feel like you're a part of the history, not just staying in some hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Nice, clean, spacious rooms”
Reviews.Author: Janine904
Reviews.Content: This is a great place to stay with a family, we had a very large room, 2adults x 2 children, the rooms are basic but perfectly adequate. The staff are very friendly, we found the breakfast delicious. 5-10 min walk to Metro station depending on kids. Bus stops very close. Would definitely stay there again. The rooftop was great for evening meals brought back to the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Facility is charming, rooms clean, staff friendly, away from the center”
Reviews.Author: jaynyc59
Reviews.Content: Hotel is in a former monastery - rooms are spread over two floor-high ceilings. Our second floor room was equal to a fifth floor in New York City. Room was clean, sheets changed very day, toilet and shower were fine. Since this is a converted medieval monastery, there were some quirks with the electrical wiring. Nothing major, just needed to keep the room card in the slot to keep the electricity running. Once we got used to the concept, it was fine. Located about ten minutes by bus from the Termini Station - bus runs every fifteen minutes most of the day, then less often at night. Also near a metro stop, but bus is preferable. Facility is charming, with beautiful church right next door. Morning breakfast was adequate. Only complaint was that when we arrived from the airport after long trans-Atlantic flight the lift was not working. We arrived the day of an incredible rain storm - the bottom of the lift was flooded, so was the Metro. Metro was out for two days. (When we went to visit the Coliseum and Forum, both were closed; we were able to see the Forum the next day, but Coliseum was still closed from the floods.) So cannot hold it against the Domus Sessoriana for the non- functioning lift. Tip - take a coach from the airport instead of the train. Coach takes multiple travelers direct to their destination, and cost is EUR 15, train would be EUR 14, and then would have to get to wherever you are staying from Termini. (Given the flooding and closing of the Metro when we arrived, this would have been impossible.) We were in Rome the third week in October, and on the property of the hotel (property is city owned in Rome), was the location for Occupy Rome. There, as in cities around the world, mostly young people were gathered to express their grievances with a society that provides the young generation with no future, while threatening cuts in social services against all of us. There were about 30 tents, with protesters cleaning laundry daily, cooking, and holding general assemblies to debate issues.

Reviews.Title: “A bit disorganized and minimalist, but nice enough”
Reviews.Author: JessJDublin
Reviews.Content: I stayed in this hotel for only one night, and the other 3 guests I arrived with stayed for a second. The hotel is quite minimal in terms of the comfort level of rooms and other services. The location is good, the hotel building and grounds are lovely, which is what I expected. Breakfast is fine, nothing special. The reception staff I had dealings with seemed under pressure; the first I encountered upon check-in was very nice and did his best for us, but the night staff I found somewhat cool, unfriendly and only grudgingly brought a second blanket for the room after being asked for it five times. The main difficulty we encountered was with our arranged pick up service, which simply didn't arrive and after numerous phone calls, which were not cheap on my mobile phone's roaming network, we were offered a second pick up more than 2 hours later from our windy and uncomfortable location. We opted for a taxi and the hotel, to be fair to them, did agree to provide a free airport drop-off to make amends. However, I'm sure that had we not made a fuss this would not have happened as I had to ask several times if this would be the case or not and it took a full day to get a response. It was a weekend and the manager was not in house. Hmm. Had I not had a phone, as many travelers didn't, we would have had no idea what was going on. I'm not sorry I chose this hotel, but the trip could have been slightly less stressful with better organization and better communication between the staff and the staff and the guests.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful hotel”
Reviews.Author: ervegard
Reviews.Content: Domus Sessoriana is a 4 star hotell. We stayed here for 2 nights and I was very amazed as it consists of 2 buildings adjacent to a cathedral. The corridor, as you can see in the photo, is very impressive. The rooms are not too big though and there was a bad sewage smell in our bathroom. Breakfast was pretty staisfactory and they have the best coffee machine in the corridor! 5 minutes out to the right you’ll find the tram and it’s very cheap to travel in Rome ; for 1 euro you can go anywhere you like within 70 minutes. As you walk out from the hotel and along a park you will end up at San Giovanni in Laterano which is the beautiful cathedral of the Church of Rome. Opposite the hotel you’ll find a very nice café with lovely gelato! Here is a fantastic cityguide: http://www.backpacking.se/ReadArticle.asp?ArticleId=251&SubMenu=2 If you only have a day: http://www.frommers.com/destinations/rome/0064020766.html

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Unique experience but not for everyone”
Reviews.Author: oleoiam
Reviews.Content: Being an older traveller, I like convenience, simplicity and budget conscious locales. I have planned multi-week, multi-city itineraries for myself and for couples who abide by the Rick Steve's philosophy of travel. All that being said, I found Domus Sessoriana to be an absolute treasure on mutilple counts. The building itself is a unique and historic venue attached to one of Rome's major churches with a fascinsating history. My first experience was in the main hall where the sight of large vaulted ceilings, expansive hallways and beautiful quiet ambience was sheer delight. And the room my son and I got the frst trip there was 3x the size of our 'chambre' in Paris. A view over the tennis court bounded by Hadrian's Wall, heated towel racks and 4 single beds which would never be found in a more mainstream hotel. As a monastery, it was exactly what I expected, which included quiet hallways, blissfully expedient sleep and elegantly simply decor. Sparse but very roomy, small tv ( I don't really care about that). Nice showers, clean and refreshing, nice towels and the convenience of said towel racks when you do laundry in the sink! Typical light breakfast was very adequate and, as I love observing the architectural aspects of these type of buildings, an adventure in the basement, or lower levels of the building. Sometimes navigating within the premises can be a bit challenging but that is a minor issue in my book. It gives one the opportunity to see more than you bargained for! A second stay there was a bit surprising as we were put in the upper, smaller rooms. Not at all how I desribed the palce to my then travelling partner. She was confused by the small and secluded room, but enjoyed the location and the overall experience as our vantage point offered us some great views of 'hidden' aspects of the building, the roof top view, the gardens, very different views of the church, Santa Croce in Gerusalemme, and the grounds. The church is a real treasure to explore! The location is fantastic as it excludes you from the busy touristy locations but is a brief stroll to San Giovanni in Laterano, then down to the Colesseum and the Roman Forum, the Baths, etc. I found it to be extremely delightful locatin and so peaceful to return to when all you want to do is re-charge before you go at exploring the treasures of Rome. You won't find bars and restaurant options. No clubs around and no in house night life but for some of us, we can find that when we want to so enjoy a secluded, refreshing and spiritually invigorating stay.

Reviews.Title: “worst place i've ever been”
Reviews.Author: herbie759
Reviews.Content: The only good thing about this place is what it looks like on the outside. The Basilica is beautiful but avoid the hotel like the plague. We've never been treated so badly! This hotel is obviously not affilliated with the church in any way. They told us the gardens (shown on their website ) belong to the adjacent monastery and not to the hotel so you are not allowed to go there. Their knowledge of the English language is selective and seems to come and go depending on their moods. There is one tall man that works at the desk which is especially mean natured. He scoffed at us when i lost my passport. I thought it may have fallen out in the cab service they use on the night before but he refused to call them to see if it had been turned in. He just kept chuckling and said we should be more worried than we were. The rooms are stark and beds hard as the sidewalk. Also the shower drains don't work so only one person can effectively shower per day. Unless you enjoy standing in cold soapy dirty water up to your ankles. The bathtowels are more like hand towels and that's if you can manage to get one at all. Also climate control is next to nonexistent. The breakfast staff was usually scowling or glaring at you and that particular neighborhood was not too keen on Americans. Definitely stay in the touristy parts of Rome for food and lodging. This place is deffinitely not upscale and at 170. euro per night it was no bargain either. The only reason we picked it was because of the religious connotation . But there was deffinitely no warm and fuzzy feeling to be had there. Our quest to feel more at one with God went severely awry when we picked this place.

Reviews.Title: “Great value for your money, convenient location”
Reviews.Author: jennandkev
Reviews.Content: If you are looking for a convenient, no frills, and economical place to stay in Rome, this is the place for you. My husband and I stayed for 4 nights and we were very pleased with the location, especially for 70 euros per night in early September. The basilica is beautiful, and the area is very quiet. The walk to the metro is about 7 minutes, or about 25 minute walk to ancient Rome. We walked early morning and late night, and always felt safe. There is a lovely cafe and bakery across the street, and some great local restaurants in the area - perfect to go to if you are looking to get away from the touristy areas. The cold breakfast served was much better than we expected, given the price of our room, and it is included in your stay. It included cheeses and meats, fresh breads and crossiants, cakes, cereals, yoghurt, fruit, juices and coffee. Our room was big enough to fit our needs, and very clean. The bed was a bit too hard for my liking. The service was great at the front desk. All of the front desk employees spoke english, and were very helpful in supporting us in trying book reservations at museums. They made phone calls for us, and even gave us a free internet pass for their internet cafe to book on line. It also seemed to be one of the last places in Rome to sell the very popular Roma Pass, that was sold out on line and everywhere else we looked into prior to our trip. Overall, we definately got our money's worth, and more than expected given the price.

Reviews.Title: “Sleep-steeped in serenity and history”
Reviews.Author: jhardcastle
Reviews.Content: Quiet, small rooms of large, marbled corridors, elegant and simple decorations, user-friendly as well as historically charming and a breathtaking location. Walking distance to Colisseum (15 mins through some great piazzas and streets). Close to metro. Great restaurant on corner opposite the piazza. Hotel staff are friendly, breakfast standard Italian fare, no problems, no fuss, a real treat. Children were accommodated at no extra cost, we were made to feel very welcome. Parking not so easy, but not difficult nearby. Wonderful.

Reviews.Title: “Simple, quaint”
Reviews.Author: nicolesouth
Reviews.Content: If you're looking to be pampered -- flat screen tv, stocked mini-fridge, room service -- this is not your hotel. If you want a clean, comfortable bed to sleep in after a long day of exploring Rome, this might be your place. This hotel was a little difficult to find as it's connected to the adjacent Basilica and doesn't have obvious signage until you're right at the entrance. However, from the very beginning, the staff was really nice and helpful. The hotel is in a quiet neighborhood, away from the really touristy area around the Colosseum, but it is only about a 15 minute walk to that area. There is also a bus line right in front of the hotel. The rooms were simple and all I needed after walking all day. The only problem I had with my room was that I had to walk quite a long way to get to it. A really long way. They offer a free breakfast, well-stocked with just about anything you might be in the mood for. The hotel itself has a lot of character and is definitely a place I will stay in again.

Reviews.Title: “Will definitely be back”
Reviews.Author: Diane C
Reviews.Content: just outside the city centre but wtihin comfortable walking distance of the Colosseum. Rooms are comfortable and clean and the breakfasts were good. Fab rooftop terrace on which to share a nice bottle of wine after a long days sightseeing. Would stay here again when I return to Rome!!

Reviews.Title: “Really liked this place, lots of character in a great location”
Reviews.Author: jmcneill817
Reviews.Content: I really liked the Domus Sessoriana. It has so much character, being in a monastery architecturally connected to the Santa Croce Basilica, one of the seven pilgrimage basilicas of Rome. There is a modern glass elevator that takes you way up to huge hallways with large clean rooms. There is a wonderful terrace at the top with a terrific view of the southern part of Rome. From my room I had a view of the Aurelian walls and San John Lateran. The guys at the front desk were very friendly and helpful. The location is perfect for Rome: within the walls in a peaceful location but close to San Giovanni metro stop. I'll definitely stay here next time I am in Rome.

Reviews.Title: “Pretty good hotel with excellent service”
Reviews.Author: Kate L
Reviews.Content: As the other reviews will tell you, this hotel is architecturally amazing (there's a beautiful rooftop patio where you can watch the sunset over the city) but doesn't have a lot of frills. The rooms are average sized with a nice bathroom. There's a small television and a small safe. One thing that may be a drawback to some people is that the beds are very firm. I personally loved it, but it may not be for everyone. Breakfast in the mornings was cold meats, cheeses, breads, pastries and cereal. Coffee and juice were also provided. Again, nothing fancy but everything was delicious. Finally, the hotel staff was amazing. Always willing to go above and beyond to help you figure out Rome. We got great restaurant recommendations, bus routes that took us straight from the hotel to the Colosseum, etc. Overall, they were awesome!

Reviews.Title: “7/10 - 3* Hotel”
Reviews.Author: rickcarnall241
Reviews.Content: In general not a bad, but basic 3* hotel. She needs updating which would bring her up to a healthy 3 and half stars. Staff were very very friendly, extremely helpful and bilingual. Rooms were small, air conditioned, but more than adequate enough. The free breakfast was pretty basic (but at least it was free !). Hotel is within walking distance to most of the major attractions. Ideal for young couples/people, not so much for families with very young children (under 5's).

Reviews.Title: “We are loving it!”
Reviews.Author: DarcyVictoria
Reviews.Content: We checked into the Domus Sessoriana on August 4th. The desk staff are very friendly and extremely helpful. Our rooms are both quite adequate with air conditioning- mandatory in this thirty-five degree heat! I'm not that keen on the breakfast but the worlds best cappuccino and croissants are just across the street. The bus stops directly in front of this beautiful old church. Have a look inside the basilica- it's absolutely beautiful!

Reviews.Title: “Very unhappy with this hotel!”
Reviews.Author: knvna
Reviews.Content: From the pictures on Trip Advisor, I thought staying here would be interesting. It wasn`t. From the pictures provided, the rooms look somewhat colorful and there are flowers. Props for the pictures only apparently. When we checked in, the man behind the desk pointed the way to the room, (across the church entrance to the other side of the building, up the stairs to the elevator, go to the 2nd floor, etc, etc) no help was offered or given. The rooms are small and dingy. The beds were the hardest we had slept on in our 3 city trip. The pillows flat as pancakes. The 7-10" television looked like it had come from the 70s and the furniture in the room was similarly as old/bad. Better to not have it at all, at least the room would have more space. The hallways and elevator are dingy and in need of repair/paint. The whole feeling of the place is cold and austere. The breakfast was nothing special. Very few items to choose from and those that were there were all cold, quick breakfast type items. We spent hours trying to find another hotels to move to, willing to walk away from the money we had spent on this hotel, just to get a good nights sleep on a proper bed, but the internet connection is so slow and there is only 1 computer so getting on it and getting numbers, then going back up to the room to make calls proved more work and time than we could do. This hotel is not centrally located. It is in the San Giovani district. Any map of the heart of Rome will show this hotel all the way down in the furthest, furthest, furthest bottom right hand corner. I called the tourist help line- and the lady on the phone agreed and advised me that I wanted to be at least 2-3 metro stops further into the city to be somewhat central. The walk to the metro is not close or convenient and could be considered sketchy if you are coming back later in the night. Both Taxi drivers as well as people in the neighborhood gave us sideways glances when we mentioned the hotel, thinking we were part of some strange religious order. I wish I could find something nice to say about this hotel, but I really can`t think of a thing.

Reviews.Title: “Good Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Katie_uk82
Reviews.Content: My partner and I have just returned from a weeks stay at the Domus sessoriana and we had a great time. This hotel is on the east side of Rome about a 20 min walk from the Colosseum and about a 10 min walk from the san Giovanni metro station. This was the first time we had stayed at this hotel and booked it based upon the reviews on trip advisor. The staff were friendly and the rooms were a reasonable size by Rome standards (big enough but don't expect loads of space). When we arrived on the sat the hotel had some problems with one of the boilers and part of the hotel had no hot water, due to it being a weekend this wasn't easy to fix so on Sunday when it was still broken we spoke to the front desk and they moved us to the part of the hotel that still had hot water. The rooms are very basic but well cleaned and the maids service the rooms every day. The bed was very hard but after a day walking around Rome we could probably have slept anywhere so it wasn't a big issue. The breakfast is European so you won't get anything hot, except coffee, but the croissants and lemon cakes were lovely. There aren’t lots of restaurants and bars around the hotel (a few on the road opposite) but you can hop on the metro and be at the Spanish steps in no time. The line A metro is undergoing work at the moment so closes at 21:00 but there are plenty of buses running that will drop you at san Giovanni in laterano which is 5 mins from the hotel. We enjoyed our stay and spent most of our time out and about in Rome. This hotel is a good but offers no extras, so if like us you want to use it as a base to come back and sleep whilst you get out and enjoy the beautiful city of Rome then you should be happy with your choice. Wherever you decide to stay Rome is a fantastic city and you will have a great time regardless, just make sure you take your walking shoes you will need them.

Reviews.Title: “A wonderful slightly quirky hotel with loads of character”
Reviews.Author: Chip47_11
Reviews.Content: The Hotel is part of the church of Santa Croce in Gerusalem, you can watch the pilgrims and religious arriving to see the relics of the True Cross kept in a side chapel. There is a crypt like breakfast area with a good buffet breakfast and a wonderful roof terrace where you look down on Roman walls and secret gardens. Rooms are well kept and bathrooms very good. Air con available all the time at no extra charge. Well situated for the bus to the centre and a healthy walk to the Colosseum. Good cafe opposite with simple food, good coffee and beer and wonderful icecream with whipped cream.

Reviews.Title: “...this hotel needs help!”
Reviews.Author: EuropeanTraveler6977
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the "Domus" about eight years ago. And, at that time, I fell in love with it! It was so incredibly unique and lovely! So, when a friend and I were planning another trip to Rome for this summer, the Domus was the one I picked, based on past experience. The location is good; the fact that there is a beautiful church connected to the hotel was special and the association with the monks etc.etc...HOWEVER, once we arrived this time, I noticed alot of changes had taken place since my last stay several years ago. And these changes were negative, unfortunately. First of all, the whole place still has great "bones", meaning that structurally, it has a beautiful interior/exterior. What I couldn't get past was how DIRTY and neglected it had become! The walls need a good cleaning and a new coat(s) of paint. There were scuffs,scratches, and gouages in the walls that indicated heavy traffic. The floors need to be scrubbed and mopped thoroughly and the bathroom shower in my room (and evidently in other rooms as evidenced by past reviews) is moldy and needs a good application of bleach. My friend was assigned a room on the fifth floor. The room was interesting as the wooden beams were exposed but the air conditioning did not work (weather was in the high 80's so you can imagine the heat in that room on the top floor). Upon calling the front desk, the receptionist told her they'd look into it. Nothing was ever "fixed" or even attempted and she also was told later there were no other rooms available. The next day, the air still was non-functioning and my friend had to call once again. This time they agreed to move her to another, cooler, room. We found that the front desk staff, when asked to take care of problems (checking the air conditioning in my friends room; the electrical outlets in my room because they did not work with my curling iron, even tho I had a proper converter that worked at the other three hotels during our lengthy vacation elsewhere in Italy) was not as accomodating as most hotels. There attitude was like "Suck it up and deal with it"-and always with a smile. Also, the breakfast we found to be minimal and I'd grade it a "C". There were a few pastries (tasted like day-old bakery) and a couple of other offerings that were at best, average. This hotel could be SO beautiful and exceptional hotel IF ONLY the owner(s) would take care of their property the way it deserves to be taken care of... It has the possiblity of being the "rose amongst the thorns" if only the owners would wake up and take care of this lovely, unique hotel! Hopefully, they will read this and take some positive action!!

Reviews.Title: “I recommend...”
Reviews.Author: jboano
Reviews.Content: It is a very different hotel. Different from everything you know... Very nice... The hotel is connected to a very beauiful church. Receptionist are very friendly and helpful. There are a delicious gelatto just crossing the street. And a mini market. Taxi from/to airport costs around EUR 50,00; It is located 10min walking to Colosseo. And 5min walking to St Giovanni train station, that takes you to main points in city. It is a simple hotel but offers everything you need, and it is a nice experience! :)

Reviews.Title: “Peace and tranquility in a chaotic city. Highly recommend!”
Reviews.Author: KathCasey
Reviews.Content: Even though it is a little outside the main touristy area, I still recommend this hotel when visiting Rome. Being a former monastery, the hotel has big staircases, long wide halls, massive rooms and in some cases, great views of Rome. Great value for money. Would stay again. Only recommendations is for free wifi (the paid wifi is overpriced) and availability of a reliable map (only a blurry photocopied map was provided) especially as a little out of the way. Also for a cheap and lively dinner at an Italian family run restaurant (five mins from hotel) head towards Saint Giovanni train station along Viale Carlo Felice. The restaurant is on the right hand side (forgot the name) with a 10 Euro fixed menu. Witnessing the crazy, family mayhem makes the meals worth the wait (that's if they remember your order).

Reviews.Title: “Not like anywhere else we've stayed”
Reviews.Author: zeke421912
Reviews.Content: The third leg of our Venice, Florence and Rome trip brought us to tthe Domus Sessoriana. Having stayed in a former convent in Venice (Hotel Santa Marina), we thought we were prepared for staying in a former monastery. This hotel is unique, to say the least. For one, the rooms are huge. The hallways are huge. And the hotel is literally attached to a working basilica which is the subject of tours conducted by "pilgrims" seeking to view the religious relics located in the reliquary within the church. The hotel was modest in its appearance (as expected), but we found the service to be good. The hotel is also located within a 5-7 minute walk to the metro which made it convenient for sightseeing. Finally, the cost was very reasonable making our entire stay enjoyable.

Reviews.Title: “A quiet section of town, historic building, monastic rooms”
Reviews.Author: milesabernethy
Reviews.Content: If you want to be in the center of Rome this isn't the place for you, we ended up in two days taking taxis multiple times. The great thing, they would call at the desk and the taxis would be there in minutes. The hotel is wedged between the historic basilica and a monastery. There is quite a routine to get to your rooms which are on looooonnnnnnngggggg, wide vaulted hallways. If only the rooms could be so grand. They were quite spare, but very clean. The staff was very, very helpful and kind. They first put us in a room requiring an extra flight of stairs, but after they saw we had our mother with us, they switched us for the second night to a better room without the flight and without an extra charge. After rushing around Rome and its craziness Santa Croce en Gerusalemme is a very quiet, safe place to be. It's also on the airport side of town which allowed us to avoid midtown and drive directly into the suburbs when we left.

Reviews.Title: “Sorely disappointed”
Reviews.Author: bacchante1026
Reviews.Content: Though the location of this hotel is desirable, the reviews did not completely reflect the conditions of the rooms. I would rate the place low for comfort: the pillows were very hard especially. The bathroom was cramped and the door opened partially for access. I had to ask for shower gel, etc. when the staff forgot to provide some. The breakfast was very limited and the overworked staff did their best to keep it stocked. Granny Smith apples were the only fruit provided. The coffee came from a machine as did the warm milk but given the number of people using it, we often had to wait until it was refilled. My overall experience was not a good one except that the 571 bus across the street takes you clear across Roma if you are willing to wait up to 30 minutes to board it. It's a very safe place but If you don't mind "monastic" surroundings, fruit flies, windows without screens, a tiny television, mold in the corners of the bathroom/shower, unusual access to some of the rooms, and noisy corridors, go for the experience!

Reviews.Title: “love hate loovvvvvvvvvvvveeeeeeeeeeeeeee”
Reviews.Author: cheerseddie
Reviews.Content: Yes, a modest improvement here and there could be made tbh. The "mini-bar" needs to be re-named a mini fridge, as it is empty and u r meant to use it and stock as u like. if u are expecting to be pampered or have room service (as in Amercan hotels) forget about it. Breakfast buffet is good with meats, cheeses, yogurts, pastries, expresso, cereal,butter, cream cheese toast, water etc. and it is free. Nothing is hot, so a pan of boiled eggs would be nice. The pastries are tooooo numerous.Water from vending machine and vending for expresso are the only other food stuffs anytime after breakfast. BUT! u r in ROME!!! and I mean in the thick of it!. This is a fab, safe, quiet, stunning, historical and archaeologically significant building, in what has to be the best spot in Rome.The3rd floor lift button takes u to the rooftop terrace, with astounding views,ample space, privacy and seating. Most of the staff are lovely i.e. more helpful and pleasant than others! Marius (a porter) speaks perfect English and is a real sweety. I have no complaint about any of the many front desk staff. Just be prepared for long walks down and up meandering halls and stairs, even after u have taken the elevator. My room must have been where the naughty monks were lodged, but i began to love its location. No bath tub for soaking in sudsy hot water and soothing toes after walking all day . But the shower was fine. All else was sublime. Buses near, as are many great bistros. I WANT TO GO BACKKKKKKKKKKKK NOWW P.S. Front desk has a corkscrew. Ciao

Reviews.Title: “A nice quiet sleep in a noisy city!!”
Reviews.Author: ElizabethBrett
Reviews.Content: What a find of a hotel! Actually its a reformed monastery so the rooms are situated within the church. A great sense of grandeur & with the old city walls surrounding it. Public transport closeby, and colosseum only 10 mins away.

Reviews.Title: “Our Roman Vacation - The Hotel -”
Reviews.Author: abuenin
Reviews.Content: The Domus is in a good location a couple of blocks from the Metro Station San Giovanni (Best travel bargain in Rome, it only cost one Euro to just about everywhere but the Airport.) The STAFF is very accommodating and informative when asked where something is. Our room was not as big as we had seen online but is was comfortable and clean, our house keeper was very sweet and attentive to all our requests, more towels, pillows, etc. The breakfast was free and plentiful. Ham and some sort of Sausage, different types of breads, juices, cereal and the "Famous Green Apples" that other reviewers have mentioned. The Basilica was very serene and inspiring not the Vatican but very special. I would recommend this hotel to family and friends because it is so peaceful and quite, comfy beds and clean rooms.

Reviews.Title: “Good Value, Quiet Location, Walking Distance to San Giovanni Metro”
Reviews.Author: usteamskier
Reviews.Content: Here’s the good: • Reasonably priced. • Clean rooms, with high ceilings • Private bath, no problem with hot water • Quads available for family of 4 (4 single beds) • 10 minutes to the San Giovanni Metro stop • Accessible on foot to the Coloseo (25 min walk) • Snack bars, restaurants, and grocery store very close by • Neighborhood is safe, even at night • Neighborhood is quiet • Includes breakfast, consisted of the same items everyday, included rolls, pastries, breads, apples a bit past their prime, corn flakes, coffee, juice, and water. Cappuccino was available if you asked. • Staff was attentive and helpful, i.e. extra towels, quilts • Includes a small room safe (large enough for netbook, iPad, etc. a standard laptop won’t fit) • Small refrigerator (like you had in college) • Nice view from the rooftop • Pictures on hotel website were accurate (no surprises!) Here’s the not so good: • Our room was cold (but the requested quilts kept us warm) • Water tastes funny • Breakfast was unimaginative, and became monotonous after 6 days • Quirky elevator • Flimsy pillow • Hard mattress (could be a positive for some) • Internet service weak (not possible to Skype call), 3 EU for 2 hours, 5 EU for 5 hours All in all, we would stay here again. The not-so-goods did not diminish our positive experience.

Reviews.Title: “Quirky hotel”
Reviews.Author: Anon036
Reviews.Content: Those looking for a regular hotel along the lines of Hilton, Holiday Inn etc may be disappointed, but this is a great quirky choice of hotel in Rome. The hotel is an extension to the church, and the decor reflects this. Since we we part of a group we saw several rooms: the rooms on the first floor are generally very large with high ceilings, whereas those on the second floor are built into the roof and are therefore smaller. All rooms have a very 'rustic' feel, with basic furniture and decoration, which may sound negative but we enjoyed it - it was part of the character of the hotel. All rooms I saw had a modern refurbished en-suite bathroom with shower, not a bath. Breakfast is a buffet, of good quality but limited - pastries, bread & conserves, cereal, cold meats, tea, coffee. There is a great Cafe across the road with friendly staff and good food, and like many italian cafes they do a cracking hot chocolate! The hotel is not particularly central, but there are a couple of Metro stations within 5 minute walk.

Reviews.Title: “Very disappointed”
Reviews.Author: herr_jb
Reviews.Content: The location of the hotel is quite good – but the management and reception desk service is not acceptable. It took 3 days to repair the heating and the last two nights were a disaster. We had a group of youths in the next two rooms. During the early hours of the first night we confronted them personally twice, asking them to please stop their unsocial behaviour. The following morning we informed the reception desk about this problem. We were promised that reception would talk to this group and furthermore we were advised to contact the reception desk directly should this happen again. Throughout the following night, the guests in these two rooms continued with their extremely antisocial behaviour. We followed the advice given to us and phoned reception directly. Over the course of the night it took us 4 phone calls to the reception desk and 2 personal confrontations with the guests until the receptionist decided to come upstairs and talk to these guests. At one point – when phoning reception - my partner even asked the receptionist to call the police because loud screams were heard from one of these rooms and we feared that a personal violation was being committed. Discussing this issue with the receptionist in the morning, it transpired that we were not the only guests who complained. I have written to the manager of the hotel (Mr A Grsi) who – after one week – has still not responded. In short, Sessariona is very happy to take your money but when it comes to fulfilling obligations from their side, they seem to be unwilling to do so.

Reviews.Title: “A wonderfully different experience staying in a church/monastery.”
Reviews.Author: wheninrome99
Reviews.Content: What better foyer than an entry to the basilica! The accommodations were beautiful, clean, quiet and had easy access to all attractions of Rome. A great place for cappuccino was right across the street. Breakfast was included and very adequate. 24 hr desk service was nice to have. I felt safe and secure as well.

Reviews.Title: “One night stop over”
Reviews.Author: TheBallingsMn
Reviews.Content: Stayed here last summer for two weeks alone and came back for one night on my honeymoon as a stay over before flying to Ireland. Very safe, clean and reasonably priced room with good breakfast.

Reviews.Title: “Atmospheric exterior and common areas, tatty rooms, poor breakfasts”
Reviews.Author: BandD59
Reviews.Content: Yes it has a unique ambiance being attached to a major Rome church, but you are staying in the hotel section, with a 140 Euro rack rate on the cheaper rooms that we were allocated. The bedrooms were tatty with peeling wallpaper, scuffed furniture and really noisy with the constant ambulance sirens day and night. The bathroom was tiny, water at best lukewarm. The continental breakfast, as previously commented by other tripadvisor members, was dull, dull, dull with no variety all week: still the same green apples the only fresh fruit item. There is no lounge area, other than a seat in reception. A real shame, as a freshen up of the rooms, an attempt to improve breakfasts and provision of a guest lounge area would make it a whole lot better place to stay. Most of our group felt the same, as did other guests.

Reviews.Title: “Great Time at a Unique Hotel”
Reviews.Author: bobp324
Reviews.Content: I travelled with a total of ten people split among three families. The rooms were huge (abliet a bit spartan) and were very clean. The bathroom was large. The hotel had great common areas (including a table, couch and chairs at each end of the longest, tallest hallway I have ever seen) as well as a great rooftop terrace that was perfect for having a glass of wine during the evening. The building is unique and is housed next to a church. While otehr reviewers commented on the street noise, we did not find this to be an issue. The metro stop is about three blocks away, and a streetcar to the Stazion Termini is about 1.5 blocks in the other direction. The neighborhood is definitely residential and somewhat "off the beaten track", but it had its own unique charm. The hotel is adjacent to an historic site, and parts of teh fourth century city wall borders the property. We found two excellent restaurants within a block of the hotel -- among the best meals we had in Rome and very reasonably priced. My only complaints were that the hotel breakfast did not offer many healthful options, and the sole elevator was small and difficult to reach. If you are looking for a hotel that is clean with large rooms and lots of attractive common areas that's in a real Roman neighbood, this is the perfect place. If you are looking for Four Seasons-like amenities, skip it.

Reviews.Title: “Great experience with good location and history”
Reviews.Author: donna54946
Reviews.Content: This hotel is located in a church. It is a historical accomodation house. We were pleased with our room, breakfast was very good with lots of variety. The late afternoon desk help was excellant, the morning desk staff was not very helpful or kind. Overall we had a pleasant stay and will stay here again if in Rome. This hotel is located near great resturants and near metro stations. We even walked to the collosium from this hotel. It was very near the train station as well. (10 min. walk)

Reviews.Title: “Feels Like A Monastery”
Reviews.Author: scvrose
Reviews.Content: We moved to this hotel to be with the rest of our friends. The location is out of the way to see most of Rome's famous sites, except for San Giovanni de Laterno which is one of our favorite churches, along with the adjorning church, Santa Croce en Gersulemme, and the Cimitero Monumentale del Verano. The rooms are large with high ceilings, but a long distance from the front desk. I had a lot of problems with the internet which was not free and walked back and forth three times in an evening. The restaurants nearby are okay. The breakfasts were standard, nothing special. No warm fuzzies. Staff was not particularly helpful.

Reviews.Title: “Unique, comfortable, tranquil”
Reviews.Author: shebrightoned
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for 3 nights while in Rome. We were pleased with the size of the room and the ceilings were possibly the highest of any room I've even slept in. The bathroom was lovely. The bed was hard and firm. The hotel was so quiet it seemed we were the only ones staying there, but morning time proved us wrong when there were others eating in the breakfast room. Breakfast was traditional Italian with meat/cheese tray, fruit, juices, cereal, yogurt and pastries (Quite a spread, really). We had a few monk sightings. The only complaint is the haul to get to the only elevator that gets you to the rooms. Up/down stairs, ramps, through very long hallways, rounding corners and corridors... It was a long annoying trek with our luggage, and there was no cart. But, overall an excellent stay. LOOKING FOR EXCELLENT LOCAL FOOD? Try Botegga Trattoria De Santis, which is #15 on the left side of the street. The Spaghetti a la Carbonara is outstanding and the wine is cheap and excellent.

Reviews.Title: “Great place to stay or pray”
Reviews.Author: palmtrees777
Reviews.Content: The hotel was about 45-50 minutes from the airport and the drive was interesting to say the least. lots of twists and turns down side streets packed with people. the hotel itself is awesome it is still a functioning church which i thought was a nice touch. the staff (valentina) was very friendly and spoke fluent english, they also knew the area well and had maps. the breakfast buffet was very good. the room was nice to sleep relax and shower but thats about it ask for an extra room key because the key activates the electric, we had to leave the room while our electronics charged so getting the extra key was a must. . there was a refrigerator which was nice because there is a grocery about 2 mins walk away. there is also a little pizza place that sells various foods, get yourself some fresh mozzerella it was the best ive ever had. the church is open till 7pm and is beautiful you can take pics but remember to be respectful. the metro was about a ten minute walk from the hotel, we used it to get to the trevi fountain which was another 15 minutes from metro walking, the vatican again about 15 minutes walk after surfacing. we took a cab from the vatican to the colosseum it was about 15 euro for the cab ride. the trevi fountain was really nice and had great picture opportunities. the vatican was completely awesome we did a private tour with when in rome tours(we also did a trip to pompeii and sorrento with them) and it was well worth the price. you are NOT allowed to take pics in the sistine chapel. we didnt go inside the colosseum because numerous tour guides told us it wasnt worth it and you can see alot from outside which was true. there are stairs across the street from the colosseum to a metro entrance near these stairs there is a little place called risto cafe, go in there and eat, great food, excellent service,vast variety of food.keep in mind that the food servers in europe are paid a salary so if you want to tip 1-2 euro is sufficient. italy was fantastic and I cannot wait to go back.

Reviews.Title: “Interesting but a bit Spartan.”
Reviews.Author: ayacastle1
Reviews.Content: This is a part of a monastery and still has the echoing corridors and although the rooms have all mod cons, ensuites, minibar (empty for your goodies), the beds are a bit hard and the echoey corridors ensure that any noise at night has the potential to disturb you. The breakfast is the usual simple cold meats and cheese, cereal etc. The Church which forms part of the building is still in use and quite interesting. The hotel is in a nice setting and has great views from the roof terrace. It is not very central, however, and there are limited bars, restaurants etc in the area. The metro is a 15 minute walk away and you may have to get to grips with the intricacies of the buses if you don't want to get a taxi. Reception staff are multilingual and helpful.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent price, good location and modern installations”
Reviews.Author: brazitRM
Reviews.Content: Even if the hotel is inside an old monastery, it's very modern for a hotel in Italy, specially Rome. Normally the hotels there are expensive and in very bad conditions. The only negative point for us was the cold. That was a very cold week in Rome and the room didn't get warm not even with the heating at the highest temperature the whole day (as we had two keys, we did it once to test how it would be). Anyway, the rooms are equipped according to the simple monk life, having really only the essential. The location was perfect as we didn't want to stay in that chaos at the town center.

Reviews.Title: “Decent experience, Inside hotel is so-so”
Reviews.Author: darlingxiexie
Reviews.Content: This hotel is inside a church, from outside it looks so beautiful and decent, cause the other side of the building live some monks. However, inside the room, so tiny and simple, you will choose this for only a place to sleep and take shower. It faces a busy street, at nights we sometimes heard lovers singing songs just below our windows. However this was very interesting experience, cause we were so tired and those noises from street wouldn't affect us, listening to mid-night love songs was not bad either!! The location a bit far from those major sight-seeings, take some walk to get the train station. Overall, this hotel is for experiencing living in a church.

Reviews.Title: “7 out of 10”
Reviews.Author: travelerLP
Reviews.Content: Positive: 1) Room has the necessary amenities: The bathroom is quite spacious for the room we had; however, it has no toilet papers when we arrived. We found out later this was because the toiler paper rack was dysfunctional, which they didn't repair and hence no toilet papers refilled. 2) Quite neat to stay in a converted monastery, which is spacious, clean, and offers quite a different experience. 3) Breakfast offered is quite complete. Negative: 1) The major one is that Internet access is NOT FREE. Didn't find out about this until arrival. In room WiFi is unavailable. Internet access costs $3 for a meager two hours and $5 for five hours. Annoying given that Internet is such an essential amenity these days. In hindsight, would book elsewhere just on this alone: $5 euro a night can get you a better place already. 2) The room isn't quiet, though the hotel is in a relatively quiet neighborhood. Was able to hear next door flushing toilets and traffic noise in the morning. 2) The location/direction given on the hotel website is hard to find. My friend and I, arriving on separate days, both had trouble locating this hotel once we walked out of the Metro station in S. Giovanni (it took me more than 30 min to finally find and walk to this hotel; my friend was simply lost and had to contact me). It's more than 500 meters away from the Metro station (had to cross major, busy streets, too).

Reviews.Title: “quiet location, spacious rooms, interesting building”
Reviews.Author: exI-nterrailer
Reviews.Content: This hotel is set in a residential area on the edge of the tourist map. parts of the building are 200 years old - the hotel literature states that it was a Roman residence prior to becoming a monastery and latterly a hotel. We had a large but spartan room. However it was clean and had all we needed. The children were disappointed that the TV did not work however we did not get roound to pointing this out to staff. We had a great view from our room of the San Giovanni in Laterano church and great views from the roof terrace (sadly too cool at this time of year to sit out in evenings). Staff speak English and are attentive. We had views over the Monastery's garden but were disappointed that we could not get access - the church however is readily accessible. transport to the city centre is varied - there are 2 buses from just outside the door - 1 to colosseum and 1 to Vatican - we managed to get to the sites relatively easily except on Sunday when the Vatican bus didn't seem to run. We weren't so lucky in getting buses back from the centre however a lot of buses go to San Giovanni and it is only a 5 min walk from there. Would recommend a Roma Pass for adults if you are there for 3 days - can just hop on and off transport and also includes entrance to major sites - then can avoid queues at Colosseum and Forum. Do however have to obtain free tickets for children (for EU residents) and may need to queue for these at sites. Public transport told is free for under 10y. Recommend Porto Corallo restaurant off Via Biancamano (behind Via Carlo Felice) - great food and service. Only drawback to our stay in this hotel is that a conference was held on our first night and we were prevented from getting to sleep early by noise from delegates then noise from trolleys being taken up and down corridor.

Reviews.Title: “low budget stay that lived up to our expectations”
Reviews.Author: alitel
Reviews.Content: We were greeted by a wide eyed receptionist who proclaimed she knew nothing about our booking,but we got the distinct impression it was all just a big hassle for her at 10.00 o'clock at night. After frantic calls to our travel agent which luckily for us we knew personally and was not the slightest bit botherd about getting out his bed to try and find out what was wrong with our reservation commented that he would sort it out in the morning.We were given a room for the night and in the morning the manager wanted to know what our problem was as he said that he found our reservation and we could have the room for our time of stay with no apology. After our basic breakfast in the prison like canteen which had the appearence of eating inside a Smarty tube , we returned to our rooms to be greeted by the smells from the old Roman sewers straight out our toilet sink ,bidet and shower drains.We went to open the Barlinnie (a Glasgow prison) styled shutters to let in some fresh air as the smells were so strong that we actually thought we were going to die of the high octain ammonia fumes,Our opened window did not greet us with wonderful splendours of paradise that we expected but just a typical skyline you would expect to see in this part of Rome. The shower was broken and dirty and was not repaired when requested,there was only the one lift that had a mind of its own and the air conditioning required a standard issue of ear plugs to help you sleep at night. All in all it was the perfect place to stay under these conditions as the chapel next door was open till 6.30pm .So you could say a prayer before bed time that might help these problems to be easily fixed.

Reviews.Title: “Well located unsual hotel”
Reviews.Author: Siinq8
Reviews.Content: We stayed in this hotel twice during our trip and found it to be brilliant for the price we paid. It's actually part of a working monastery complex with an amazing church at the centre of it making it quite unique. The guys on the reception desk were very helpful and all other staff were very pleasant and helpful. We stayed in two different rooms during our two vists and both were spotlessly clean and quiet. They are fairly basically furnished in keeping with the ecclesiastical setting but were comfortable nonetheless with plenty of storage, nice bathrooms, electronic safe and a reasonably priced mini bar. The only grumbles we had were pretty much the same as other reviewers - hopeless air conditioning (the second room we stayed in was in the attics - very quaint but roasting hot at night presumably as the terracotta roof tiles had stored the heat from the day, although the hotel did provide a huge fan) and small pillows (although our room did have a spare). The TV was also tiny with few channels but we did not travel all that way to watch TV! The location is great, being a short walk to the metro and there is a bus stop directly opposite. However, Rome is quite an accessible city and we actually walked to most places. The view from the roof terrace is amazing and it's a shame they don't have a cafe or restaurant on it. A buffet breakfast was included in the room rate and contrary to several other reviewers we found it to be spot on, with a plentiful and tasty selection of cheese, cold meats, breads, yoghurt, fruit, lovely cakes, cereal, tea, coffee, juice, etc. The breakfast room did get quite busy at times but we always managed to get a table. Occasionally some food items ran out but the staff happily brought in more. We would defintely use this hotel again when in Rome - it was excellent value for money and the plus points more than outweighed any of the niggles we had.

Reviews.Title: “Stunning Hotel...”
Reviews.Author: wykesy
Reviews.Content: Amazing, stayed here on honeymoon but would recommend for anyone, beautiful and massive rooms in a converted monastery only 5 mins walk from the collosum.

Reviews.Title: “Stylish and spiritually satisfying”
Reviews.Author: Meme_Denise
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Dormus Sessoriana, knowing that it was attached to Santa Croce en Gerusaleme. Our stay in Rome was to visit some of the famous sites, religious and secular. We wanted somewhere that would be quiet yet central enough to be a good base. Dormus Sessoriana didn't dissapoint these requirements. We also chose it because on eof us is ordained and thought it might be convenient to pop into the church for morning and evening offices - again we were far from disappointed, and rather, the hotel and church combination was an inspiration. The hotel accomodation is clean and very comfortable. The buffet breakfast more than met our needs. The rooms are stylish and the air conditioning invaluable, and generally we were very pleased. It's location is within a gentle stroll of the nearest tram, underground and bus routes, and when the C Line is completed this will only get better. The roof terrace is lovely to sit on during the evening and gives a fantastic vista of St John's. Any disappointments? The website gave us the impression that we would have access to the garden and pool, but in fact this wasn't available. Its a shame that evening meals are not available in the hotel, though there are restaurants and take-aways available very locally (don't do as we did though and hunt towards St John's and the Coliseum - head up the road immediately opposite instead!) Over-all - we will stay at this comfortable and competitively priced hotel when we next visit Rome and have already recommended it to others.

Reviews.Title: “OK hotel in historic surroundings - something different”
Reviews.Author: Markus_Sparkus
Reviews.Content: We booked this hotel because it seemed a bit different - and we weren't disappointed in this respect. The building and its surrounding gardens/basilica are magnificent. The hotel however, is nothing special. It's just OK. The rooms were clean and acceptable, the breakfast was OK (continental style - with plenty to choose from). However, we came away feeling that this hotel could have been really special with a little bit of TLC. We enjoyed our stay in Rome, and for the price, this hotel was a reasonably good find. The hotel's roof terrace was a lovely place to retire to at the end of the day, with a bottle of wine and to watch the sun go down... (However, no bar or sun parasols if you wanted to chill out in the daytime - the heat is intense!). The hotel is within walking distance to the main attractions and it is well linked to bus and underground network which is handy. No problem getting around at all. In summary, I'd say this is an acceptable hotel, set in magnificent surroundings, and relatively close to main attractions.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful friendly hotel within easy access of transport routes to the city”
Reviews.Author: tinminer
Reviews.Content: This was a lovely respite from our daily touring of Rome - we walked miles and saw as much of the city as we could fit into the seven days we were there. We had a room on the fourth floor at the front of this hotel. There are two wings on one side of the basilica - Aurelian and the Conventual wings. The Conventual wing is at the back of the building which is probably a little quieter. The beautiful basilica is in the center of the hotel with the monastary on the other side. The refrectory and internet facilities are accessed using the room key which makes it very secure. All rooms are non smoking but our German neighbours did not conform to this house rule and we occasionally had the smell of cigarette smoke in our room. The staff were very helpful and friendly and any problems were dealt with quickly. Our room had the basics with excellent air conditioning and a safe for valuables. It would have been nice to have had tea / coffeee making facilities in the room. The staff at reception were also very knowledgable and helpful about how to get around the city - buses metros etc. from the hotel the main tourist attractions can be accessed by bus or metro. The two metro stations are San Giovanni and the Manzoni stops on the A line. This can also access the B line and the Colloseum. Buses 571 and 649 stop just outside the hotel - 571 back fromthe city , 649 to the termini. Eating out can be quite expensive anywhere in Rome. There are some nice restaurants in Via S Croce opposite the hotel and the average cost of a one course meal for two with a drink is 30 euros. We found that the supermarket in Via S Croce made lovely paninins for 1.50 euros as opposed to 3-5 euros in the city. Ideal for taking for lunches. The Villa Borghese a very nice park for eating lunch and this can be easily accessed from the Spagna stop on the metro. access to the park can be made from the metro station in the relative cool using escalators and moving walkways or outside in the sun across the piazza just up from the metro stop. Water can be expensive if you buy it - we found that the water fountains that are dotted around the city offered free, refreshing and delicious water whenever we wanted to refill our bottles.We bought a Roma Pass which is good value for money if you are staying for three days. It can give free entry for three attractions and metro / bus travel. We topped up with a metro ticket for the rest of our stay. The food was not that exciting anywhere in Rome and as I am a vegetarian the limitations of choice made eating a necessity rather than enjoyable. There is a limit to how tomatoes, mozarella and salad with pasta or bread can be enticing. Castle S Angelo is well worth visiting for the views across to the vatican city and it has a bar at the top. We had a late flight back and the hotel looked after our cases for the day. The lady on reception is particularly helpful. We would recommend this as a good 3 star hotel for people able to walk or stroll 10 minutes to the metro or two minutes to the bus stops.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Exterior & Interior - But Customer Service Non Existance”
Reviews.Author: romelover09
Reviews.Content: After reading the other reviews we asked that our hotel room be on the garden side, when we arrived we found our room over looking the road, the air conditioning not working and our bedroom that should have been three seperate beds was a double and a childrens sized bed! When we asked for something to be done we were met with surly staff saying that nothing could happen until the next day, after much insistance we eventually got another child's bed, and promised that we would be moved the following day. This was a pain as we were only there for two nights. The next room was bigger with 3 proper beds, the actual hotel was clean and the breakfast was fantastic, fresh bread, ham and cheese, with great cakes and danishes for breakfast along with tea (all be it cold) coffee and orange juice. There was a mini bar in the hotel room, but no place for drinking water, would have been nice for some tea making facilites other than one coffee machine that was broken for most of the visit. You will only get one pillow and heaven forbid that you ask for more - they don't like it! PLEASE DO NOT ASK THE HOTEL WHERE TO GO FOR DINNER - WE WERE RIPPED OFF WHEN WE ASKED, THE RESTAURANT HAD A TABLE FOR 12 READY AND WE ORDERED WINE AT 6.00 EUROS A BOTTLE, AND WERE CHARGED 15 EUROS A BOTTLE, COFFEE WAS COLD AND THE FOOD TERRIBLE. Look around and never take the first restaurant you see. You will be charged for bread if you eat it when they put it on the table - it is not complimentry like in England. Another tip, get the hotel you do chose to order you a taxi to collect you from the airport it is a lot cheaper that way round.

Reviews.Title: “Monastic Fantastic”
Reviews.Author: thesilverhustler
Reviews.Content: We booked this hotel through Easyjet as a birthday getaway and had a swell time. The hotel is easy to get to from Termini, with about a 25 minute walk through what appears to be the Chinatown area of the city. The hotel, which is easily accessible from a door to the right of the main entrance, is just 5 minutes walk from the San Giovanni metro stop at the bottom right corner of most central-Rome maps. There is a small two minute trek from the front door to the hotel rooms, but we found that this added to the charm and the security of the stay. We asked for a room in the new wing and were lucky to get one of the bigger rooms there - room 209 - which was a fair distance from the main road and overlooked the inner courtyard. We had no problems with the king size bed, which was firm but comfortable. The bathroom was also a decent size, as was the huge wardrobe. Our room was mega warm, perhaps to warm the bones of some of the elderly folk staying there, so we often opened the windows for an intake of fresh air. There is aircon in the rooms but we rarely twiddled with it. We wouldn't say that our stay as noisy, though you can hear sounds from adjacent rooms, such as shower water etc, I wouldn't go as far as to say that this disrupted the peace. We ate a hearty breakfast every morning, picking from cereals, toast with or without ham and cheese, yoghurt, pastries and a limited selection of fruit. If you wanted a bit more variety you could pop to the gelataria/delicatessen across the road, which offered plenty more delights at reasonable prices. It helped if you could speak basic italian at the deli, as I discovered on some occasions! The staff at the Domus Sessoriana were friendly and efficient and they also sold the Roma pass - which is well worth it at the new price of 23 euros. If you're looking for a bite to eat, we tried the Cipriani, which was nice enough, but ate far more at the restaurant on the corner behind the Cipriani, which I think was called the Restauranta Porto Corolla or something or other!!!! Incidentally, don't go to the Japanese restaurant on Via Filiberto as we found the food very overpriced and nothing to write home about.

Reviews.Title: “Great location but VERY LOUD INSIDE!”
Reviews.Author: CentralFLchick
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a stay at the Domus Sessoriana in Rome. Great location - we walked to San Clemente (don't miss this place), Colosseum, Forum, Capitol Museum, Spanish Steps, Trevi fountain - everywhere. REALLY fabulous restaurant right down the street "Cipriani" - just ask the man at the desk at the hotel. The hotel is clean and nice - but lots of walking to get to your room - some stairs and some elevators. The rooms are VERY SMALL and rustic but the bathrooms are large and plush! Also very loud - if anyone walks by your room it resonates through the whole place. The staff was very efficient , very nice - but we were told it was impossible to get water at 7pm and impossible to get another pillow at all. Beds extremely lumpy and hard. Probably would not stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing building!”
Reviews.Author: Ingriddv
Reviews.Content: This hotel is build in an old monastry. One of the wings is still prohibited for tourists and monks live here. The building is amazing and the service is great. You get welcomed like you are in a 5 star hotel! Our room was very tidy and quite big. On the roof is a terrace which looks out on the monks garden. When you look over there you feel like you just walked in the middle ages. For younger couples it might be a bit boring, because in the area where the hotel is located there is not much to do. Beside that the hotel is not that close to the inner city, so you have to walk a fair bit or catch public transport. But overall, this is a great place to stay at.

Reviews.Title: “For tourists only”
Reviews.Author: Girlfriend1
Reviews.Content: This hotel is indeed an interesting property, and the staff is friendly and helpful, but it is not at all suitable for business travelers. My corporate travel agent booked a stay here for me because it was only a couple of blocks from the place I was working and was on that company's recommended list. (I have since asked the business to take it off their list.) I checked in on a Sunday, and discovered that the room, while perfectly clean, was really basic. As tourist, I would have been fine with it--it's what I would expect from a 3-star hotel and the price is very reasonable for Rome. However: They took full payment for 4 nights upon check-in, and then would not allow me to cancel--they have a 48-hour cancellation policy, so all I could do would be to cancel my last night, after I was done working, just sleeping over before leaving. That was hardly worth bothering with, to change hotels for just that one night, so I stayed. I obtained a pass for use of the WiFi in the room (10 euros for 7 hours). Unfortunately, I could not get on the Internet at all--and neither could a colleague in a different room (at least they warned her ahead of time that it might not work). I returned the password info, and asked for it to be credited to my account; they were agreeable to that, but I was still unable to work! Other things were less important but still annoying: there is no restaurant or room service, which when jet-lagged and working until 10 pm, is often preferable to going out. The hotel really is pretty far from everything--had to take taxis everwhere, especially to meet my clients staying in the center of Rome. Again, the subway is usually fine for me, but not in business attire, at night, in the pouring rain, to meet clients for dinner. There is no laundry service--might not have been a problem except that I was stuck with a white shirt with tomato stains on it and no way to get it cleaned. I could not even effectively wash it in the sink, as there was no stopper for the drain. No laundry service meant no laundry bag either, but fortunately I bought some bottled water and used the plastic bag the grocery store gave me for my dirty clothes. No stationery, so no envelopes in which to file my receipts. (I found a plastic bag to use for this purpose also.) No full-length mirror in the room; only the feeblest of hair dryers. No real desk set up (not that it mattered since I could not get on the Internet anyway). I realize these all sound like tiny matters, but when you are traveling for work to multiple cities, the small conveniences you take for granted in most hotels become relatively important. The only really serious issue was the lack of internet access, but it was not a good choice for a busy work schedule. All in all, a good deal for a tourist on a budget, but not okay for a working person. Also should mention that there are a good number of stairs that you cannot bypass with the lift, and of course there is no bell desk, so you have to manage your luggage on your own.

Reviews.Title: “A bit disappointing”
Reviews.Author: Bugsy47
Reviews.Content: Most points already well covered - we found the room, en-suite area and beds on the small side. Breakfast OK, rooms etc generally clean. The (mainly vegetable) garden is sited in an old Roman amphitheatre and there are certain days when you can enter and be shown round for a fee. We had a room facing the square and main road and found it very noisy some nights especially on the Saturday when there was a lot of emergency vehicle noise, music blaring and someone playing football outside throughout a large part of the night. Rooms elsewhere may well be much quieter.

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyed our stay in this peaceful hotel that's a bit different”
Reviews.Author: Woodchester
Reviews.Content: We (a family of 4 including 2 teenagers aged 17 and 14) stayed for 4 nights and particularly enjoyed the character and general ambiance of the place. We had a room on the 2nd floor which contained 4 single beds with ensuite facilities and a balcony. The room was very clean and simply but adequately furnished. The buffet breakfasts were good with a wide selection on offer. The only possible criticism was the disappointing orange juice and lack of fruit apart from apples. The staff were pleasant and helpful. The full price, as for most hotels we investigated to stay at fairly near the centre of Rome, is quite steep. However, it's worth searching the internet for special deals out of the main season (including April). In the evenings there are a number of reasonably priced places to eat located close to the hotel, so one doesn't have to walk far after a tiring day seeing the sights of Rome. The hotel is easy to find being part of the monastery complex attached to the historic Santa Croce in Gerusalemme church. The S. Giovanni Metro station (Line A) is only a ten minute walk away and the Colosseum and Palatine Hill complex is also within easy walking distance (~20 minutes). If you have a spare hour, the National Museum of Musical Instruments, which is next door, is well worth a visit. It has well written information (in English) about the fascinating collection of exhibits.

Reviews.Title: “Domus Sessoriana, unique, you will not be disappointed !”
Reviews.Author: j3dnight
Reviews.Content: We stayed here five nights September 2007. I cannot rave enough about this hotel. We loved it ! It is attached to a beautiful church, the rooftop terrace is enormous and the views, you will never forget them. It is very clean. Ask for a room with a balcony. I definitely would stay here again. Also the front desk sells the Romapass and are very helpful with giving you directions for buses, metro etc, Enjoy ! There are photos of Domus Sessorian on a link on my profile page, unfortunately I could not upload them here because the files were too big.

Reviews.Title: “magical”
Reviews.Author: paintedeyes1
Reviews.Content: My sister and I toured Sicily and Rome. We enjoyed this hotel the most. Within walking distance of the Piazza San Giovanni, Collosium, Pantheon, and Forum. 15 minutes by car to Vatican. Close to airport. Hotel clerks were all most helpful and spoke english. Very clean. Saw the Pope perform an open air mass 5-10 minute walk away at San Giovanni Piazza.

Reviews.Title: “Amazingly unique building!!! Lavish!”
Reviews.Author: celine41
Reviews.Content: Beautiful- Right next to a beautiful church. Character property (was a former monastic dwelling) and yet very modern interior (lifts etc)!! Beautiful view from the roof. Very polite staff. Best breakfast you will get in italy!! Great pastry shop down the road ahead of it. Only down fall was distance from the centre- was a bit difficult to find too! Fantastic and such a beautiful building!! So much history in that building!

Reviews.Title: “Better than most”
Reviews.Author: mediamutts
