Reviews.Content: Great location, away from the city center. Two blocks to the train. Good breakfast, nothing fancy but you won't go away hungry. Clean room and bathrooms, clean sheets. Uncomfortable beds, but we were so tired from sightseeing that we slept great. Friendly and helpful staff. The only problem were the teenagers that hung out in front of the hotel until 2 :00 - 3:00 a.m. They were loud, blasting their music from their scooters everynight. Hmmm, I thought they only did that in NY or NJ! Other than that it was a great hotel in an excellent location. Two blocks away there are tons of stores and restaurants.

Reviews.Title: “an ideal base”
Reviews.Author: blakefamily
Reviews.Content: stayed here for a 3 night break, it is slightly outside central rome but close enough to access the metro and buses. the rooms were comfortable and clean but we experienced a little street noise as our room was at the front. the breakfast was great and plentiful. the staff are helpful and will endeavour to communicate in english. the view from the roof garden is a must. we enjoyed our stay here and would recomend this hotel for those who like something a little different.

Reviews.Title: “Historical place but nothing fancy off the city center”
Reviews.Author: el_toro2
Reviews.Content: Summary: the hotel has a good value for the money but the website appears a little too fancy for what it is. Arrival: spend the money for a personal shuttle from the airport to avoid all the hassle with public transport and walking if you do not know the way around. Location: In the south east part of the city center, quiet area with a few good restaurants around. South of the hotel is the Via Appia Nuova with fancy shopping place for clothes. 10min walk to San Giovanni in Laterano and metro station. 30min walk to Colosseum unless you choose bus or metro. Breakfast: breakfast is simple Italian style but covers all the basic needs to get started for a day of sight seeing. Staff was always busy in in cleaning up the tables and replenishing the buffet. Rooms: Spacious, tidy and high ceilings, noise proof windows that can be entirely shaded against sun light. Air conditioning was in winter mode according to receptionist. It was useless for the heat in Rome at the end of October. We opened the windows during the night to get some fresh and cool air but there was a loud traffic noise. Since we were exhausted from the 12h day trips in Rome we still got our rest, despite the noise. We would recommend a room in the right wing towards the patio and garden of the monastery next door. General: Nice view on the terrase on the 3rd floor but no catering as a picture on the webite suggests. Internet access (fee) in the hallway was down two times but immediately fixed.

Reviews.Title: “Would stay here again.”
Reviews.Author: Rover4
Reviews.Content: Location, location, location. Bus stop is just across the square, so you can be at the Rome Termini in 15 minutes. From there you can get on a train, subway, or bus anywhere...either within the city or outside. Room was comfortable, clean and well appointed. Hotel staff very professional. Two women traveling without husbands felt very safe both at the Domus and surrounding neighborhood. There is an excellent cafe across the square...their ciambella alone (say "chahm-BELL-ah" -- a huge raised donut with sugar), is worth the trip! Trattoria Bottega on same block was likewise excellent. Unlike many convent/monastery properties, the Domus has no curfew. Bountiful breakfast served from seven to ten.

Reviews.Title: “A haven in Rome”
Reviews.Author: stretchs
Reviews.Content: We were a family of 2 adults and 1 child, so we had a large triple room, with a separate bathroom. The room was not lavishly furnished but clean with one large window high in the wall and very high ceilings. Half the site still functions as a monestry and there is a lovely church and garden. The roof top terrace was just superb for watching the sun go down over Rome with a bottle of wine. Breakfast was served downstairs and we thought very good by european standards, plenty of everything. The staff were very helpful and even allowed us to check in early at 10.30am when we arrived exhausted from our 23 hour flight. We noted some other travellers had trouble finding the place but we found it with no difficulty at all when we walked from Termini station, about 30 minutes. You just go to the smaller door to the right of the main church entrance. We did the walk to/from the station 3 times and also walked to the Coloseum and back. The nearest metro was about a 10 minute walk away and we did use this as well. We thoroughly enjoyed our stay as we found the location to be just slightly away from the general bustle of Rome and rather peaceful. There are still enough places to eat situated in the streets nearby to please most tastes. We would stay there again tomorrow as it was a unique experience.

Reviews.Title: “A Roman hotel with atmosphere and history”
Reviews.Author: Hakluyt
Reviews.Content: I stated here at the end of May and found it a comfortable and characterful retreat from the busy sightseeing of the day. The room was enormous, overlooking the monks' garden. It was also spotlessly clean. The staff were helpful, and it was easy to reach the main sites by bus or taxi. Breakfast was good, to set you up for a day of sightseeing. Incidentally it used to be a monastery, founded on the site of a Roman palace. Talk about atmosphere! I would recommend it to travellers; perhaps not so much to tourists who want something ritzy.

Reviews.Title: “A relaxing, unique experience”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Let's get the downside out of the way! It's not in the fashionable part of town - if it was, we could never have afforded to stay there. It doesn't have a bar and the air-con was a bit noisy. But when we come back to Rome, we'll go back to it for certain. Thjis place is amazing. It is part of the monastery and church of Santa Croce, but don't think you need to be religious to enjoy it. However, people with a strong, non-Christian faith would not like it. The room with its en suite was a good size, spotlessly clean, with solid wood furniture, wrought iron bed, terracotta tiled floor, lofty ceiling, gorgeous fixtures and gloriously firm, springy mattress. If you want fitted carpets and fussy wallpaper, this place with its simple washed and stencilled walls is not for you, but we loved the calm, cool ambience, the tall windows (the ceilings must be 20ft high!), the long, arched corridors - the perfect antidote to 7 hours in the Vatican Museums or a heavy day of sighseeing. There is a safe in the wardrobe - use it, because the metro is a thieves'paradise. Only take out what you need and make sure you keep it literally close to your chest in secret pockets etc. We met two couples - not at the hotel - who had been robbed on the metro. The breakfast is buffet style and there is lots to choose from, so unless you expect egg and bacon you should not be disappointed: yoghurt, fruit juice, coffee, croissants, rolls, cheese, cereal, jams, cake, fruit... It was a bit chilly to be up on the rooftop terrace in the evening, but that would be the place to take a picnic and bottle of wine in the summer. I presume they put chairs up there then. Nearest metro is San Giovanni Lateran - just a 5 min stroll away. Bus 649 goes up to Termini from the road opposite the hotel, and No 3 bus goes from outside the hotel. In short, the disadvantages of the location are far outstripped by the advantages.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent - good location, room size, clean, helpful staff....”
Reviews.Author: mark2008
Reviews.Content: Nothing like you've stayed in before...unless you've stayed in a converted monastery in the centre of an Italian city before!! Highly recommend - rooms are a good size for a city centre, quiet, clean, helpful staff with excellent English spoken. No restaurant or bar but plenty in the city. Breakfast included. Great view of the city at sunset from the roof terrace. If Holiday Inn with twin doubles and room service is your thing then don't stay here and then write a negative report...

Reviews.Title: “thank God for A/C”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Great place to stay and relax from seeing the sites. Excellent location and the staff was very pleasant. went during one of the hottest summers in europe, it was nice to come back and cool off in the a/c room. rooms are nicely furnished too. the breakfast was something to look forward to every morning. me and my wife(then girlfriend) would stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Hated the place”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband I along with another couple booked 2 rooms in this dump. Make sure when you book this hotel that you are given rooms in the new(renovated)wing otherwise you will be staying at an old room that some priest must have been dorming in about 50 years ago.Basically it was worst then any motel you can be in. It is not that cheap compared to what the more center hotels would cost and are closer to town. In any case think twice before you book this dump.

Reviews.Title: “Unusual hotel and a winner!”
Reviews.Author: Pengaman
Reviews.Content: We were a party of 3 adults and 2 teenagers and stayed at the hotel for 5 nights between Christmas and New Year. As many other reviewers have said, don't expect too many creature comforts here - the hotel would benefit from a restaurant and a coffee room / bar to relax in after a day's sightseeing but we knew it didn't have these before we went so we weren't disappointed not to find them there. The rooms are clean, of adequate size and are well serviced. The staff were friendly and helpful. Breakfast is a good quality and plentiful continental version. There are a number of good restaurants within a 10 minute walk. In particular we could recommend Charly's Sauciere in Via S. Giovanni in Laterano (reservation required) and al Cavallino Bianco in Via Emanuele Filiberto. At no time did we find the locality intimidating despite several late night walks back to the hotel. We stuck with the metro for travelling into the centre of Rome - the San Giovanni station is 5 minutes walk from the hotel. One definite winner for us was that the hotel was so different to the run of the mill ones that you find in most city centres. The basilica to which the hotel is attached is beautiful and well worth a visit during your stay. All in all a very pleasant hotel and one to which we would readily return.

Reviews.Title: “Basic and with sacred atmosphere”
Reviews.Author: Rune&B
Reviews.Content: We spent 4 nights at the end of 2005 at Domus Sessoriana. We liked the hotel. Being almost inside the basicilca gives it a nice atmosphere. Good breakfast, helpful staff, large room. A couple of drawbacks though: the water wasn't as hot as we would have liked it to be, specially in the morning. The location is all right for visiting sights. Bus stop right outside and not far from the Metro. It's a bit unconvenient to return at night though. We didn't realize that some buses stopped early in the evening and the Metro stops at about midnight. This resulted in a couple of unplanned taxitrips (10-12 Euro).

Reviews.Title: “Superb hotel”
Reviews.Author: Mrs Mopp
Reviews.Content: We stayed in this hotel with our two teenage daughters for a week at the end of July/beginning of August. We had a quad room which was huge. The beds were comfortable (though a little firm until we got used to them). The shower room was small but adequate, with shower, toilet, bidet and separate washbasin area. There were plenty of clean towels every day. We found the staff very polite and helpful - whatever question we asked them, they knew the answer! They all spoke excellent English, though we did attempt to speak Italian to them! The lift was not working properly when we arrived but once reported was fixed within a couple of hours. Air conditioning in the bedroom was very welcome, as we stayed there during a heatwave. Breakfast was brilliant and even if you went for breakfast later there was plenty of food. The location was good - 5 minutes from San Giovanni metro, with plenty of small pizzerias over the road or in San Giovanni itself. We enjoyed the walk through the park to the metro each day and we always felt safe in that area. We rarely used buses or trams because the metro was so handy. Someone did attempt to pick my husband's pocket (unsuccessfully) when we were getting on the metro one day at Piramide(but we kept all our notes in money belts under our clothing). The view from the terrace in the evenings was superb with sunset views over San Giovanni cathedral. All in all, a superb hotel for the price and we would recommend it to anyone.

Reviews.Title: “An amazing hotel in a Basilica”
Reviews.Author: Ozi
Reviews.Content: For a low cost option within (actually on) the ancient wall of Rome, we found the Domus Sessoriana perfect. It was only a 5 minute walk to get to S. Giovania Metro station and train's to the major shopping locations in Rome, Termini Station and it is right on the number 3 tram/bus line for a quick trip to the Colusseum and Forum area. Yet it was out of the way enough to access local restaurants without the tourist markup. The hotel is a destination in itself, built around the Holy Cross in Jerusalem Basilica. The hotel is basic, very clean and quiet, with airconditioning which was critical in summer. Our double room was average size for Italy. We had been in much smaller elsewhere. The breakfast is a standard cold buffet with fresh rolls, cheese, meat, cereals and fruit. There was plenty available. There is a rooftop terrace where you can take some Chianti or Prosseco and watch sunsets over St Peter's that are nothing short of glorius on a clear day. After 4 nights there, we where very comfortable with the hotel, the friendly staff and the priests wandering around doing their work. We would not hesitate in returning to the Domus Sessoriana if we get back to Rome. It is hard to find at first (because it really does not look like a hotel) but once found it was worth the effort. Three cheers to our travel agent who booked it for us.

Reviews.Title: “Pope John Paul II week”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Just by coincident, my room reservations at the Domus Sessoriana was made for April 4th, 2005, only 2 days after Pope John Paul II passed away. My reservations to this hotel was made a few months in advance. I lucked out in more than one way. I got to view the body of Pope John, and I got to stay in a hotel/church that I found to be very welcoming. This hotel is nice, clean, organized. The hotel staff are polite. The breakfast is good and the breakfast tables are kept clean. I arrived in Rome via train to the Termini station from Paris in the evening. It was around 10pm when I got out the San Giovanni metro stop from the subway train (you can catch the metro subway train from the Termini station at get off at the San Giovanni subway stop). When I got off the San Giovanni stop, I started to walk and look around for the hotel. I got lost on the streets of Rome at 10pm at night, I knew that I was near the Hotel but I was having a hard time to find it. I asked a few Italians on various streets if they knew where the hotel was. Few spoke English well, but they managed to understand me enough to assist trying to help me. I found the Italian people to be very friendly and helpful throughout my 2 week stay in Rome and other cities in Italy. Eventually, I found the hotel on my own after 1 hour of searching on foot. In my mind, I had remember seeing a distinct image of the front of the hotel from a picture of it I saw on this website. Thank God for pictures on the Internet...or else I would have been lost in Rome. The hotel is across the street from The Great Brick Wall of centuries pass. You should notice a big clock right behind the hotel the towers over the hotel. The clock looks as tall as Big Ben in London, but not as pretty. The clock the broken because the hands do not move. If you really, really get lost on finding this hotel, and if you are scared of being alone by yourself on the streets of Rome. Do not be afraid, the steets of Rome are great, and safe. I would have no problem watching the streets at any time day or night. Like I said, the Italians are great and friendly. Anyway, if worst comes to worst, when you get off at San Giovanni, you could take the Tram 3, it will pass right in front of the hotel. Although, this may not be needed because the San Giovanni stop at only a couple blocks from the hotel. I will upload a picture of the hotel that I took. Please notice the big clock standing over it. Good Luck, Al

Reviews.Title: “Charming and Solid.”
Reviews.Author: wayneyoung
Reviews.Content: Seems like those who have been disappointed by Domus were those who expected a five-star hotel. It's not. It's super for what it is: a historic, converted monastery. Domus is comfortable (leaning somewhat towards spartan) but retains a lot of charm, and rates are very attractive for a large city like Rome. We also thought the location (which is somewhat residential for such a central location) was convenient. Staff is unpolished (if you are used to five-star service, for instance), but they are eager and friendly. I'm not sure why some people are so set on having eggs for breakfast: Domus' breakfast is typical of many hotels on the European continent: cold cuts, cheese, bread (excellent chocolate croissants that are baked daily) and more than good enough coffee. We stayed in two different rooms. The first was large with spiral staircase and charm, but also too cavernous: a touch cold for the early part of the year, and the shower drains slow (what do you expect in such a historic location, right?); the second room was much smaller, cozier and warmer, and everything in the room worked well, so I suspect rooms vary a lot.

Reviews.Title: “Spartan experience”
Reviews.Author: XenaWarriorPrincess
Reviews.Content: Our stay was an unusual experience and was interesting from a historical point of view, however, the experience as a hotel was less than satisfactory. If you want a spartan experience, then look no further than the Domus Sessoriana in Rome. The room was spartan to say the least, the air-conditioning blew out hot air and the breakfast was so basic, that they should not have even bothered laying anything out. The hotel is quite far from the main sites, but accessible by bus and the nearest metro station is a good 15 minutes walk away. I would recommend visting this place, but not staying here as its too basic and does not meet traveller's needs.

Reviews.Title: “Molto Bene!!! Near the sites, but far enough from them too”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I had an excellent stay here and would recommend the Domus Serssoriana to all our friends and family. Americans were NOT treated badly, in fact we were given royal service, and I being pregnant at the time, needed rest, comfort and a few amenities, and the staff was so accommodating! The first night there it rained so hard that the power went out, but that was not the fault of the hotel; and in fact the rain pouring just outside the grand foyer of the basilica gates, was one of the most beautiful experiences. There is a large rooftop patio, great for a nice picnic dinner under the stars or sunbathing during the day. Additionally, DS is located right off the Roma Tram, so getting to the sites was a quick ride up the road. It was nice to be near the Coliseum and other sites, yet not right by them. The DS had so many quaint restaurants and cafes nearby, so you could get away from the tourist areas and enjoy some authentic food and charm. MOLTO BENE!!!

Reviews.Title: “Unique, but once is enough”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the Domus Sessoriana for four nights on our honeymoon in December 2004. As Christian history buffs, the thought of staying in a building that IS history and holds significant importance to Christianity was very appealing to us. Although by no means a bad hotel, compared to our other experiences at cheaper hotels throughout Italy, we left with a sense that with a little more searching, we could have probably found a better hotel for about the same price. Here are my ratings for the hotel. Staff: 4/10 They were not rude, but neither were they especially friendly. For the duration of our stay, the heater in our room was broken, and despite repeated complaints to the front desk, nothing was ever done about it. Unlike the photos on this site, the window in our room was tiny, and when opened revealed scaffolding on the side of the wall, severely limiting our view of the outside, and blocking 90% of sunlight from entering the room. Although we also complained about this and requested to be moved to another room, our requests were denied (despite the fact that they were not fully booked). Location: 7/10 In true Alitalia fashion, our flight arrived 1 hour late, causing us to miss the last metro to the hotel. The night we arrived in Rome was pouring rain, and we found ourselves lining up 2.5 hours for a taxi with over 100 other people. Granted, this was no fault of the hotel, but for people arriving on late flights into Rome, you may wish to consider staying somewhere closer to Termini station. For the remainder of our stay, we found the hotel to be convenient for travel throughout the city. Cleanliness: 4/10 The floor was not cleaned once during our stay, with dust and HAIR from either the previous guest or maid found in various parts of the room. Bed sheets, towels were changed daily. There was no bathtub in the room, which was quite disappointing, as we would have liked to relax in a warm bath after a long day of sightseeing. Breakfast: 9/10 The one redeeming feature of this hotel was its breakfast, which was quite generous compared to other 3 star places we had stayed at.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel - excellent price-quality average”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Hotel Domus Sessoriana - Just the first look at the hotel gives away it's uniqueness, the integration with the church is awesome. The check-in went swiftly, and the rooms were spacy. If you like a lot of decoration, thick carpets and a house like atmosphere, you'll be disappointed, as the hotel really is kept in the old church style. Very modest, just the essentials, and high ceilings. Although everything of luxury you need is there (tv, minibar, fully equipped bathroom, ...), you also get a feeling of living in a monastery. The breakfast was what I expect of a city break hotel: I've read that breakfasts in Rome were poor, but the selection was enough (cereals, yoghurt, a piece of fruit, bread, and some sweet breakfast snacks) and most of all, the quality was very good. The hotel isn't in the city centre, but a 15-20 minute walk brings you right to the city centre, and a subway station is a 5 minute walk. The neighboorhood is ok, and can be compared to the most of Rome city areas (a lot of grafitti!). The downside for the hotel is a lack of a bar, which is a bit annoying because in the neighbourhood there is not really a place for a nightcap. The clerks at the reception are nice and helpful.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel- don't take any notice of bad reviews.”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This is a great hotel, we really enjoyed our time here. I was almost put off by the bad reviews, but am glad I still booked it! The review which mentions the smell of urine?! The smell I think they may be referring to is the rainwater running down the limestone blocks in the small open air courtyard or atrium between lobby and main building, the lack of sun gives damp earthy smell! Its not urine! You walk thru this section in about 4 secs! The hotel is very secure. The adjoining church has high locked gates, when the church is shut. There is always a man at the lobby, whom you have to walk passed to get in to the hotel, which is more secure than most hotels, where anyone can walk in with the other hundred guests. You need a key card to enter your room. The rooms are great, clean and spacious. With a TV, mini bar (v cheap), nice hard matresses, clean new, large wardrobes. The bathroom had a great powershower, clean towels every day. I booked on hotels, reasonable price, no probs with the booking. The location- well slightly out the centre, but very quiet- NOT seedy location! Hardly Brixton or the Bronx! Easy access to centre- 1Eur for 10 min tram ride to coloseum! buses run frequently thru night, bus and tram stops opp the hotel and train is not far to walk to. Quiet location, so much better than staying near the busy central station. The hotel staff all speak English and are very helpful. There are not many restaurants near the hotel, but most people tend to stay in the centre for food- not really a problem if you are only there for short break. The breakfast- great. Obv not your Amercian Buffet portions/a full English, but great European selection- meat, cheese, cereals, rolls, croissants that are freshly made! The dinning hall is a long corridor, and was fine off peak- but I can imagine it being busy during peak times. The hotel def has the wow factor, especially when you first walk up to it! There are the high ceilings and long corridors as seen in the pics. There is a great view from the roof terrace. The hotel is built into the old house of St Helena, who brought back lots of relics from her crusades, which are housed in the adjoining church- inc thorns from the crown of Jesus, fragments of his cross and the finger of St Thomas! This is not the hotel if you are used to be waited on and having the luxury of your run of the mill Hilton/Best western! This hotel is for people who want something slightly different from their stay in Rome! We would def stay at this hotel again on our next visit to Rome!!

Reviews.Title: “I fell in love with this hotel!”
Reviews.Author: TravelingEducator
Reviews.Content: The Domus Sessoriana was a hotel I will definitely revisit when in Rome again! The staff was totally professional and extremely helpful and kind from the managers to the waiters. The exterior can be confusing if you are looking for the typical hotel front because the glassed hotel entrance is adjacent to the front of the church. It is magnificent architecture and inside you'll find the quiet and reverent environment of a scaled-down St. Peter's Cathedral. The ceilings in the very long and main hallway are high and arched-absolutely beautiful! Original paintings are displayed on easels and placed throughout this main hallway and in other areas around the hotel. My mother (79) and I stayed in a room from which the access was through the hotel lobby and across the interior front circular hall of the church foyer. It was extremely quiet at all times and the room was spotless and very comfortable. The air-conditioning never failed us (and it was HOT in Rome on the days we visited...high 90's). The beds were comfortable and the little round window in our room overlooked the picturesque circular drive out front. The complimentary breakfast offered was very adequate and situated in another long, rectangular room with that same arched ceiling treatment as the larger main hallway upstairs. When we first arrived, a white-haired Italian gentleman who was sweeping the church foyer, saw us struggling with our luggage and was immediately there at our side trying to help. Although there was a language barrier, there was no mistaking his desire to help someone in need of a hand. He carried our luggage to our door and did not hang around for a tip. On the morning of our departure he was there, as usual, sweeping the church foyer and as I was about to leave, I ran back to him and pressed several coins into his hand as a thank you for all his help. I'll never forget the image of him smiling and waving to us as our van pulled away from this WONDERFUL hotel! I thought I was in heaven!

Reviews.Title: “They are rude to Americans”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Domus 2 years ago and it was fine. This time I had a travel agency book my group of 13 people - 6 six rooms and had a voucher for each one. Some of my friends arrived the day before I did and one of my friends didn't have a reservation, they told her, so they made her pay again. The next day I checked in and had a room as big as a closet - my luggage didn't even fit in the room. I asked to be moved and they said they didn't have any rooms and that the travel agent should have requested a nice room.- I then asked about my friend that had to pay again and I asked why the Domus didn't call the travel agency - keep in mind the agency books with the Domus all the time. They told me that was my problem not theirs. The night before we left we asked the front desk to order us 2 big vans (taxis) for the airport ,they told us the price and we told them the time. The next morning when we were ready to be picked up and no taxi's were there, I went to the front desk to ask where they were and they said "Oh you didn't confirm them. The Domus is not a hotel where Americans should stay, They are very Rude and if you have a problem there they refuse to help

Reviews.Title: “Space, Tiles and Atmosphere”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I like unfussy, uncluttered decor, cleanliness, space and atmosphere - and something a bit different - so I was destined to like the Domus Sessoriana. On approaching the hotel, there is no written indication. However, if you know that it is a converted section of the Santa Croce church complex, you don't need the brains of an archbishop to figure that the large open door to the right of the basilica's main entrance leads to reception. We visited in a hot, late August, so the high, vaulted ceilings and acres of tiled floors were a cool refuge. I particularly liked the space outside the room - not so much a corridor as a long, high hall. We could see from the room plan on our fire notice that our four-bed room was the largest on the floor. It was clean, airy and simply furnished. More than one chair would have been welcome but the essentials were there - mini-bar, TV, safe, air conditioning and lashings of fresh crisp, white towels every day. There were small problems that the management should have quickly corrected, such as a bathroom door that would not completely close and no sink plug - but these were easy to work around. Having stayed in only 2 Italian hotels, I found the buffet breakfast adequate, but not as generous as in a similar grade in Germany or the UK. It is eaten in an interesting, elongated undercroft. The staff were helpful, polite and spoke good English. The 571 bus from around the corner takes you straight to the city centre and the Vatican. Unfortunately, in late August, the nearest source of bus tickets, a tobacconist opposite the hotel, was closed for the holidays. So, for the first trip of each day, we could not take advantage of the nearby bus stop - although a weekly ticket would crack this. The area around the hotel is not Belgravia but it is not threatening and contains a good dose of ancient city wall. Although there are no top class restaurants nearby, there are a couple of averages up the road and a useful bar/patisserie directly opposite. Our prize discovery was a brisk 15-minute walk up the Via P. Eugenio - the ice cream hall "Palazzo Del Freddo" of Giovanni Fassi. If you like lots of fussy trimmings and close, intimate surroundings, this may not be the hotel for you. Neither can I speak for the smaller rooms or for winter, when stone floors or the spacious roof terrace may not be so appropriate. But, if I return to Rome, the Domus is where I want to be.

Reviews.Title: “Bates Motel Roma”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Anyone who says this hotel is acceptable has very, very low standards for hotels. The location is horrible, miles from the center of Rome and in a dangerous neighboorhood. The hotel itself is isolated and creepy. The staff was rude and not helpful. The hotel was so horrible we left after 1 night and went to find a new hotel, but the manager attempted to charge us twice the rate we were told at check in. Our room had no beds, only 4 cots that were very uncomfortable and sloped so that your feet were about 6 inches above yoru head when you lied down. The lights in the room flickered on and off. The shower had little water pressure. The room smelled like cheap disnefectant. The phone didn't work and we had no phone book. A horrible hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Unique experience and great value”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I was a little hesitant about my booking after reading some of the earlier reviews, but can ensure travellers that there is little to worry about with this hotel. DS is about a 10 minute walk in a straight line from the Basilica of San Giovanni in Laterno. Once at the church of San Croce, enter via the glass doors to the right of the main church entrance. DS has very tidy and well appointed rooms and a brilliant rooftop that overlooks the Roman walls, the ruins and the church itself. In the evening, you can sit there and watch the sun set over the basilica of San Giovanni and watch the little bats wheel around in the belfry. In terms of location, the hotel is reasonably close to the colosseo, but I found it better to walk up to the San Giovanni metro station and take trains into the centre of the city. While it true that it is not next to any major restaurant strips, I found several very good Italian restaurants, a Chinese restaurant and a bakery just down the road (if you walk straight ahead from the church). The area is quite safe. Grafitti lines the walls and rag-traders line the footpath, but this is common in many places in Rome, and I felt much more comfortable walking back along the park than past the Termini or other popular hotel locations. DS will be one of my best memories of Rome and I strongly recommend it (as long as you don't mind a few Metro or tram trips).

Reviews.Title: “Just like a Country Club”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This hotel was unbelivable. I thought because it was so inexpensive it was going to be a dump but I could nto have been more wrong. As we walked through the basement to get to the elavator there was a noticable smell of dampness and for sure I now knew the place was a dump. When the elavator opend to the first floor I thought I was at my country club. I was led through a huge hallway (the one on the website with the chairs in the front) and my room was on the end. I had a Huge very clean and new looking room. Of course things were not perfect, my shower door never closed but I would def. go back. I loved this hotel and the staff was excellent not to mention the tram was right outside the hotel as well as the metro. I loved it here. Bravo

Reviews.Title: “Chek you booking”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Beware! Check your booking. We booked on internet through a booking service we have used before and received a confirmation number. We arrived and the hotel claimed we were not booked in. They denied receiving an email which I had a copy of and left us high and dry for our 3 nights in Rome. Not impressed with their service at all. The booking service was legitimate and has confimation but the Domus staff forgot to put the reservation in their system. They were not helpful and blamed booking service.

Reviews.Title: “Fantasic hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We enjoyed a brilliant short break at this hotel. We received a warm, friendly welcome from Guiseppe at the reception desk who kindly gave us a fantastic room (more like a suite). The building was beautiful, the staff helpful and friendly and only a 5/10 min walk to the sights. It was more than we expected from a 'budget' hotel and we would definately go back

Reviews.Title: “wonderful hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: After reading the above reviews, I was uncertain as to what we would find. I found the hotel to be fantastic. It is less then a 10 minute walk to the metro station. It is centrally located. I found the hotel to be very clean (no trace of a urine smell), the staff was very friendly, the room was very large (as far as European standards). The ambience was fantastic. The breakfast was very good. I do not have anything negative to say at all about the hotel, other than my stay was too short! I would definitely stay at this hotel again.
